title: 108_s553
content: The "Business Checking Freedom Act of 2003" authorizes interest-bearing transaction accounts for all businesses. The "Business Checking Freedom Act of 2003" allows depository institutions to offer accounts with up to 24 transfers per month for any purpose, considered transaction accounts unless determined otherwise by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. The "Payment of Interest on Reserves at Federal Reserve Banks" is addressed in Section 3. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow balances maintained at a Federal reserve bank by depository institutions to earn interest at rates not exceeding short-term interest rates, to be paid quarterly. The Board may regulate the payment and distribution of these earnings to the depository institutions. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at a Federal reserve bank. Responsibilities for crediting and distributing earnings are outlined for depository institutions, Federal home loan banks, and the National Credit Union Administration Central Liquidity Facility. The term 'depository institution' is defined for this purpose. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances held at a Federal reserve bank. The term 'depository institution' includes trust companies, corporations under section 25A, branches of foreign banks, and other specified entities. Amendments are made to Section 19 of the Act regarding member banks and technical adjustments. Amendments are made to the Federal Reserve Act to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances held at a Federal reserve bank. This includes trust companies, corporations under section 25A, branches of foreign banks, and other specified entities. Subsections are modified in Section 19 of the Act regarding member banks and technical adjustments. SEC. 4. INCREASED FEDERAL RESERVE BOARD FLEXIBILITY IN SETTING RESERVE REQUIREMENTS. Amendments to the Federal Reserve Act allow for a ratio not greater than 3 percent (which may be zero) and not less than 8 percent (which may be zero) in setting reserve requirements. SEC. 5. TRANSFER OF FEDERAL RESERVE SURPLUSES. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow additional transfers from surplus funds to cover interest payments for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. The Federal Reserve Board determines the amount each bank pays annually from 2003 to 2007. No bank can replenish its surplus fund during this period. Additionally, any surplus fund amount can be transferred to the Treasury during the same fiscal years. The surplus fund of any Federal reserve bank exceeding 3 percent of the paid-in capital and surplus of member banks must be transferred to the Treasury through 2007.
